text:
This is to comment on the proposal to reduce era regulations based on executive order 13777. The EPA regulations should not be reduced- rather they should be strengthened. Failure to protect our air and water and other environmental resources now will have lasting impacts that according to scientific evidence will not be able to be corrected at a later date.

Regulations should not be removed solely because they eliminate jobs. This is short-sighted. Reducing environmental regulations today and creating more environmental degradation today will eliminate future jobs and also make our future workforce less healthy. It is archaic to think that jobs of the last century need to be preserved and will be the jobs we need for this century.

Further, the EPA regulations are not unnecessary- they are absolutely necessary for our health and future. They also are not ineffective. They are effective and evidence has shown that they have resulted in companies making positive changes that they would not otherwise have made that have made all of us healthier. They also have many times created jobs in the environmental sector and in new industries.

Further when comparing costs to benefits, the analysis must be done over long not short periods of time. As with almost any decision in life, the immediate costs may be small, but the longterm costs to our health and food supply and air could be extremely large. It is government responsibility to think about the future and the next generations even when we as citizens forget to do so. No regulation should be delated for cost benefits unless they are calculated over many generations.

The executive order item (iv) "create a serious inconsistency or otherwise interfere with regulatory reform initiatives and policies" makes no sense whatsoever. This statement says that we get rid of regulations when we (or corporate interests) want to do so. That is totally irresponsible government. No regulation should be removed for this reason.
EPA should strengthen its regulations and protect our environment and that of future generations.

text:
The work the EPA does is important. It is broad and comprehensive because, well, the environment is all around us. And either we take care of it, or it will take care of us, once and for all. I vehemently protest the rollback of the EPA's mission. I particularly am appalled at the idea that this rollback would be done to satisfy businesses rather than being based on actual science.

Not an exhaustive list, but I definitely believe the following.
--Maintain the clean power plan,
--Maintain evaporative emission standards for small engines
--Maintain the greenhouse gas mandatory reporting rule.

--Implement the 2015 ozone NAAQS.

--Maintain uranium mine tailings monitoring. (I can't even believe this has to be said!)

Maintain the Renewable Fuel Standard. Businesses have already prepared to meet these standards.

--As someone with asthma, my life may actually depend on maintaining the national ambient air quality standard for fine particulate matter.

A rule should not be considered obsolete unless the science says it is no longer needed. Not your donors, Scott. You hold the lives of billions in your hands.

text:
Regulations on carbon emissions should be strengthened, not weakened. The goal: closing every power plant generating carbon dioxide, including ones as small as portable generators and automobile engines. This will also result in companies like Exxon-Mobil, Ford, and -- as we've already seen happening -- Peabody Energy having to change their focus or fold.

Instead of making it easier to contaminate the atmosphere for our electricity, start building solar farms above every parking lot, every large building roof, and every multi-lane highway. The demand for solar panels will require the opening of new factories, which you should ensure are opened in the US, instead of being built in Mexico or China. Those factories will mean jobs. The construction of solar farms will also generate jobs for years, if not decades.

There are also now practical electric cars. Another way to generate jobs would be to build out an infrastructure for supporting them. All those parking lots? In addition to putting solar panels over them, put metered charging stations at every parking space. Add a per kWh meter tax to supplement what would then be a declining fuel tax to balance out the funding.

Fossil fuels should be reserved for industrial processes that can use nothing else and quickly eliminated from anywhere they possibly can. Further, there should be government-funded research into new processes, not dependent on fossil fuels, for those remaining industries.

Finally, as the current administration -- like all recent Republican administrations -- seems to be entirely focused on making it easier for corporations at the expense of actual living people, change the fundamental structure of corporations. Right now, corporations have as their first duty to increase shareholder value. That duty should be no more important than fourth in the hierarchy. Ahead of it should be their customers, their employees, and the communities in which they operate. Eternal growth is the rule cancer follows; it should not be one anything in our society tries to emulate.

text:
I am concerned about the conclusion in your environmental compliance that the proposed additional anchorages would not have a direct or cumulative impact on the resources of the area. I appreciate that the increased anchorages may be for improved safety and reduction of collisions, but filling the bays with more ships will have an impact on water quality, noise pollution, light pollution and wildlife using the area. The proposed anchorages in the north, Vendovi, William Point and Jack Island will impact waterfowl populations that use the area. The emissions from additional ship traffic and anchorages will impact the air quality for these birds. There is frequently a dark smog forming over these areas because of the existing level of shipping traffic and staging at anchorage. In your environmental review of this proposal, please include assessments of the existing anchorages, their sizes and numbers, and air and water quality impacts. Also include the direct and cumulative impacts of adding the proposed anchorages.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment.

text: Vehicle traffic is becoming worse with each passing season and that on-demand bridge openings are contributing to vehicle traffic backups on the Bridge of Lions.  For this reason I support the proposed modification of extending the twice an hour draw opening period from 7:00am to 9:00pm daily, and preclude the draw bridge from opening at 3:30pm on weekends and federal holidays. It's not logical to think that one person on a boat can, on demand, stop hundreds of people in cars. On busy holiday weekends the on demand delays can build up and clog the roads leading to the bridge for hours, impacting the lives of hundreds of people. The hour and half hour delays are bad enough. It makes good sense to make these changes in an effort to increase traffic flow.

text:
After reading the initiative it is obvious, at least to me, that the goal of this order is of a political nature. While I agree with the efforts of efficiency, we need to utilize reason and rational thought in the process of gaining efficiency. In decades past we've seen the banning of CFC's which in turn helped to stem the growth of health and environmental problems related to solar radiation. We've seen air quality dramatically improve in areas like Los Angeles and New York City due to regulations imposed on gases and waste products projected into the atmosphere. This has improved the quality of life for countless individuals as well as ecosystems. President Nixon understood this endeavor when he signed into existence the Environmental Protection Agency. The establishment of this agency as well as the legislative and regulatory measures taken since were above politics. They were put in place so that all people and our society, including the ecosystem our society exists in, can continue to support us as well as allow our society to progress and evolve. Putting countless lives at risk to achieve a short term political goal is completely unacceptable.

I do hope that multiple independent scientific studies are admitted as evidence as well as the conclusions of scientists within the EPA it's self. I hope that objective and empirical conclusions are reached and by a non-partisan task force established without a personal or political agenda. So long as the agenda is only the protection and flourishing of our society as a whole I'm not opposed. The wording in this executive order is disconcerting at it's core. From President Theodore Roosevelt to President Barrack Obama we've seen administrations that protect our nation and it's populace without partisanship. There's no doubt in my mind we will see that again in short order. I do hope we don't, as a nation, fumble here, cost lives and countless tax dollars, simply to make a short term political statement.

docAbstract: Executive Order 13777, issued 2/24/17, directs agencies to establish a Regulatory Reform Task Force to oversee the evaluation of existing regulations to make recommendations about potential repeal, replacement, or modification.

text:
While I applaud the effort to review regulations for any that are outdated or no longer relevant and make appropriate changes to them, I am concerned by what appears to be a "slash and burn" approach adopted by our current administration, particularly with regards to environmental and health & safety regulations.

The Clean Air Act is a great example. In the report "Benefits and Costs of the Clean Air Act 1990-2020, the Second Prospective Study," for example, found that in 2010 there were an estimated 160,000 deaths prevented PER YEAR due to the reduction of particulate pollution in the atmosphere. The report also estimated that it saved 13,000,000 work days per year, which also helps reduce company costs by reducing absenteeism.

What I do support is reducing the administrative burden of certain regulations. As long as companies and individuals are complying with the law, and essentially not polluting, I don't think there should be a lot of administrative hurdles or red tape put in the way to "prove" they're complying with the law. If anything, I would propose that the agency, as much as possible, reduce the administrative burden for regular reporting, but vastly increase the penalties and fines for noncompliance. If a company isn't polluting, they shouldn't be fined because they forgot to check a box or fill out a form. They should, however, be fined into oblivion the moment they actually do something that is counter to the regulations/law.

docAbstract: Executive Order 13777, issued 2/24/17, directs agencies to establish a Regulatory Reform Task Force to oversee the evaluation of existing regulations to make recommendations about potential repeal, replacement, or modification.

text:
The purpose of environmental regulation is to establish minimum standards to help safeguard the public health and protect America's air, water, and land. Most existing EPA regulations have been developed in response to either immediate, extant environmental hazards or to forestall specific, credible environmental threats. Many of those dangers affect broad segments of the public: For instance, water contaminated with lead and other poisons can devastate entire communities, while air pollution affects tens of millions of Americans. The maintenance of regulations to limit those dangers is therefore a matter of overriding public interest.

Environmental regulations, by their nature, do not become obsolete. If a specific danger has become less prevalent since the enactment of associated regulations, that is evidence of the regulations' effectiveness and necessity, not a sign that they are no longer required. If you lock your home to protect your property from theft, would you decide the locks are no longer necessary because nothing has been stolen lately? Hardly!

EPA's areas of statutory responsibility are admittedly of great legal and technical complexity, which may occasionally give rise to certain contradictions or unintended conflicts. Where such conflicts appear, EPA should address them *individually*, with careful deliberation based on sound science and in consideration of public and other stakeholder comments.

For the agency to engage in a broad-based, open-ended "review" of literally thousands of existing regulations does not suggest either careful deliberation or good faith. Rather, it signals an intention to recklessly gut decades of carefully crafted environment policy, risking the health and welfare of millions of Americans in the process.

The intended review and the executive order on which it is based are therefore contrary to the overriding interests of the public and a threat to public health and safety. Such a far-reaching review is singularly inappropriate and should not proceed.

text:
It's so disheartening to see such vague guidance in these recommendations for reform. I'm not against reform, but statements such as these leave the criteria entirely up to the political agendas of those on the task force without any input/feedback from the public. You're taking comments on reform from the public without the public having any clear understanding of the criteria for the reform.

In response to the following:
"(i) Eliminate jobs, or inhibit job creation;
(ii) are outdated, unnecessary, or ineffective;
(iii) impose costs that exceed benefits;"
I ask, by what measure(s)? Are the measures narrow, short-sighted, and solely monetarily based, or are they holistic and with a respect for long-term effects on an inconceivably interconnected world and environment? Without any clarity around the lens that will be used in identifying regulation subject to reform, I stand firmly against this EO. Without details, this amounts to carte blanche.

Please protect what is invaluable to all of us from those who are unable and/or unwilling to appreciate that most things that don't come with a price tag are more important than money.

text:
In the case of CAFO's (concentrated animal feeding operations or factory farms), there are not ENOUGH regulations, and the existing laws and rules under the Clean Water Act, designed to protect the environment and public health, need to be strengthened and enforced. The EPA defines CAFOs as point sources which discharge their pollution to the waters of the United States. Inconsistent state regulatory efforts and legal fights from the livestock industry have already kept the EPA from fulfilling their legally bound duty to protect the American people. Agricultural corporations, beholden to their shareholders to maximize profit by any means, including externalizing the costs of mitigating the effects of their own pollution and environmental degradation, cannot be counted on to regulate themselves. We need a strong EPA!

In North Carolina alone there are approximately the same number of hogs in factory farms as there are people living in the state. These 10 million animals produce the fecal waste equivalent to 100 million humans and the feces are stored in open manure lagoons polluting the air and ground water. This volume of feces can be compared to the entire population of the east coast flushing their toilets into North Carolina. Agricultural fertilizer and livestock waste are major sources of nitrogen and phosphorus pollution, threatening the entirety of nearby waterways. "Manure and wastewater from AFOs have the potential to contribute pollutants such as nitrogen and phosphorus, organic matter, sediments, pathogens, hormones, and antibiotics to the environment." * And people living near these factory farms, largely low income and communities of color, are ill and dying with disproportionately high rates of cancer and respiratory illnesses caused from the air and water pollution produced by these unregulated livestock operations.

Lenient laws and regulations have made it far too easy for agribusiness polluters. And now the number of CAFOs in the U.S. is climbing due to the increased demand for meat exports from developing countries. This will have a huge impact not only in point source water pollution but also in greenhouse gasses - methane emissions from manure lagoons and increased nitrous oxide released from fertilizer used to grow feed. I want the EPA to hold these polluters accountable by increased oversight and tighter regulations - not less!

*EPA. National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) https://www.epa.gov/npdes/animal-feeding-operations-afos

text:
I write to support the authorization of field release of the genetically engineered diamondback moth (DBM) in New York..

Agricultural pests, such as the DBM, need control in farmers' fields. At present farmers use chemical pesticides and DBM's develop pesticide resistance. Farmers need new approaches to pest control. The field trial of genetically modified DBMs begins to provide the data needed to learn about efficacy and safety of a new approach -- through genetic constructs in the pest itself.

As regards safety, the genetic construct builds upon related technology for mosquito control for dengue fever. Brazil and the Cayman Islands have approved this mosquito control technology as safe and effective. The insects become their own source of lethality. Not only does the genetic construct control the insect, but the lethality makes the construct a self-disappearing construct in the environment. Field trials for the genetically modified DBM are very low risk in light of the prior testing and approval of related, basically identical, technology.

Furthermore, the DBM approach to pest control builds upon sterile-insect technology that has been used for screw worm, med-fly, and other pests since the 1950s. I am not aware of any physical, biological, or human health harms having occurred in sixty years of the adoption and use of sterile-insect technology. The difference between these earlier sterile-insect technology examples and the diamondback moth is simply in the method by which the trait is created in the DBM a genetic construct for female lethality accompanied by a tracing construct for red fluorescence.

I have perused the Environmental Assessment. The Environmental Assessment (December 2016) considers and discusses, at length, the potential for physical, biological or human health harms for each component and then cumulatively. The EA concludes that there is no significant impact. The EA is thorough and careful. Most importantly, the EA is correct that the field release by Cornell of the genetically engineered diamondback moth will have no significant impact on the environment.

In light of the EA and the underlying reasons for the release (set forth in the second, third, and fourth paragraphs of this comment), USDA-APHIS should issue the permit authorization.

Sincerely yours,

Drew L. Kershen
Earl Sneed Centennial Professor of Law (Emeritus)
University of Oklahoma College of Law

text:
In reference to the proposed changes to Indicator C3, Pennsylvania's Bureau of Early Intervention Services (BEIS) is in agreement with the addition of wording that clarifies that child outcome data should be reported only for infants and toddlers who have received early intervention services for at least six months. However, in order to make state-to-state comparisons more effective, additional clarification is needed to define the start point of the six month period. Pennsylvania would recommend using the date of the IFSP as the beginning of the six month time period since it is a data point that is already collected by states and signals the beginning of provision of early intervention services to infants and toddlers. Pennsylvania's BEIS also recommends that this clarification be included in the Part B preschool Indicator B6 and that the measurement of child outcome data be the same for both Indicators C3 and B6. Additional clarification is needed on the expectation for performance on this indicator given the changes in measurement in both the numerator and denominator.

In reference to the proposed changes to Part C Indicator 11, Pennsylvania's BEIS recommends that the language be updated to remove any redundancies in content that is requested in several sections of the SSIP. It is also recommended that requests for any information or documents that were provided in previous submissions, be deleted from the proposed changes. Information or documents that have been updated since the last submission should be included, but if the material has not changed, there should not be a need to resubmit it.

text:
As a PTA member, I appreciate the opportunity to comment on the U.S. Department of Education's (ED) revised state template for the consolidated state plan under the Every Student Succeeds Act (ESSA). National PTA is the oldest and largest volunteer child advocacy association in the United States, with congresses in all 50 states, Washington DC, Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico and Europe. Since 1897, National PTA has been a strong advocate and a reputable resource for empowering all families to effectively engage in their child's education.

The enactment of ESSA and the ongoing implementation process of the law has allowed parents and families more opportunities to be involved in their child's education at the school, district and state level. The statutory requirement that parents be "meaningfully consulted" as stakeholders in the development of state and local education plans will allow us to become closer to making every child's potential a reality.

Our members are committed to educating and empowering all families to be active participants in the state and local implementation of ESSA to ensure equity and opportunity for all students. We are extremely disappointed that stakeholder engagement is no longer prioritized in the revised consolidated state plan template. The removal of the requirement for states to explain how they have engaged stakeholders undermines Section 1111(a)(1)(A) of ESSA, which requires state education agencies to meaningfully consult a wide variety of stakeholders that are vital to the implementation and success of the law.

The U.S. Department of Education must require a description of stakeholder engagement in its ESSA consolidated state plan template, including who was consulted, what they were consulted on and how stakeholder feedback was incorporated into the state plan. Furthermore, it is imperative that states explain to all stakeholders-especially parents and families-how students and schools will be impacted under the new state accountability system.

Authentic and robust stakeholder engagement must occur at all levels-the state, school district and school-so that there is transparency and accountability for the educational system and opportunities provided to our nation's youth.

State education agencies (SEAs) should provide the necessary support and oversight of local education agency (LEA) plans to ensure authentic stakeholder engagement also occurs at the school district level. Within the description of stakeholder engagement in the state plan, the state should describe how it will provide guidance and best practices for stakeholder engagement so that school districts can create strong LEA plans that meet the needs of all students in their communities.

Parents and their children are consumers of our nation's public education system, and parents are essential partners in education. However, they haven't always been included at the decision-making table, which has caused confusion, mistrust and backlash when new initiatives-whether at the federal, state and local level-have been considered and implemented. We have learned from the implementation of other education initiatives that engaging all stakeholders-especially parents-is critical, not optional. Stakeholders, particularly parents, play a critical role in the successful implementation of ESSA and ensuring that all children receive a quality education by providing valuable input and holding states and districts accountable.

It is imperative that the consolidated state plan template requires a clear and thorough description of how stakeholders were engaged to develop the state plan. Through meaningful consultation of all stakeholders, states and school districts can provide a blueprint to improve education, provide educational equity for all children and make sure every child is prepared for long-term success through ESSA.

I am committed to educating and empowering all parents and families to be engaged in their child's education, and specifically be involved in the ESSA implementation process. Our association values our strong and long-standing relationship with ED and we look forward to continuing to collaborate to make every child's potential a reality.

docAbstract: We are advising the public that the Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service has received a petition from ArborGen Inc. seeking a determination of nonregulated status of Freeze Tolerant Eucalyptus lines designated 427 and 435, which have been genetically engineered (GE) to be more tolerant of cold conditions. The incorporation of the GE trait allows this eucalyptus hybrid to be grown in a broader geographic area than non-GE eucalyptus hybrid trees. The petition has been submitted in accordance with our regulations concerning the introduction of certain GE organisms and products. We are making available for public comment the ArborGen Inc. petition and are soliciting comments on whether these GE eucalyptus lines are likely to pose a plant pest risk. We are also announcing to the public our intent to prepare an environmental impact statement (EIS) on the action with regard to the petition for nonregulated status, identifying potential issues and alternatives that may be studied in the EIS, and requesting public comments to further delineate the scope of the alternatives and environmental impacts and issues. We are also announcing that APHIS will be hosting two virtual meetings during the comment period. The purpose of the meetings will be to further delineate the scope of alternatives and environmental impacts and issues discussed in the EIS.

text:
Docket ID: APHIS-2014-0056

This is about a proposal by Cornell University to test the effectiveness and safety of a method of controlling diamondback moths by releasing males genetically engineered to have a female autocide trait.

It is hard for me to see a long term danger to the environment from release of such moths. They are not expected to persist in the environment. If, for some unanticipated reason, they were indeed able to become established as a feral species, there is still no likely way in which they would be any more harmful than wild diamondback moths.

It remains to be proven that this technique for reducing the population of this pest species will be effective or economically viable. That is why the realistic testing under this application is needed.

All proposals for any and all genetic engineering in agriculture, ever, always provokes a knee-jerk opposition. USDA should take note of any realistic concerns, and modify the permit add management of such concerns. But the knee-jerk opposition is best ignored.

docAbstract: Executive Order 13777, issued 2/24/17, directs agencies to establish a Regulatory Reform Task Force to oversee the evaluation of existing regulations to make recommendations about potential repeal, replacement, or modification.

text:
The EPA was setup in 1970 to protect the health and environment by writing and enforcing regulations based on laws passed. I remember a time before the EPA when fish kills from pollution was common, exhaust fumes from cars and trucks was thick in the air and I had to take a bus to the hospital to treat my asthma. The EPA needs to expand the protection of our environment for a sustainable future. It is clear that the folks who are regulated do not want the regulations but citizens want to protect and our environment. It is far more expensive to prevent environmental disasters than to clean them up. I do not support any reduction in the EPAs funding or limits to the scope of the work. I support the need to increase our regulations and to find new ways to produce energy that is not harmful to the environment.

In New Jersey, we want clean water that we can drink, a healthy eco system and a clean up off existing contamination. Currently, NJ has contamination in our drinking water including hexavalent chromium found in many water systems. Lead is found in our local schools and N.J. Has Among Highest Risks For Lead-Contaminated Water in U.S.

More power to the EPA not the corporations, gas and coal industries who support the EO.
